summary: Introduced as H.R. 352, the "Motorist Tax Abuse Act" aims to prevent the implementation of New York City's congestion pricing plan. The bill proposes an amendment to the Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act of 1991. This amendment would specifically prohibit the Secretary of Transportation from establishing or maintaining "cordon pricing"—a system of charging vehicles to enter a specific area—for the Central Business District Tolling Program in New York City. The legislation effectively seeks to use federal law to block the city's plan to toll vehicles entering a designated zone in Manhattan.
